sentence: Procter & Gamble will report fiscal first-quarter earnings on Tuesday, with investors looking for the household products maker to keep benefitting from pandemic trends.
The shares also got at least one price target increase ahead of the results.
P&G (PG) shares have risen about 14% in 2020, as the company’s cleaning products saw increased demand throughout the Covid-19 crisis.

The company delivered an upbeat fiscal fourth-quarter report in July—building on strength from earlier in the year—as consumers snapped up brands like Mr. Clean and Bounty paper towels, both in the U.S. as well as in key markets like China.
On Monday, Truist analyst Bill Chappell raised his price target on P&G to $150 from $125, although he maintained a Hold rating on the stock.

He writes that the move comes as the sector as a whole as has seen multiples expand, although he’s hesitant to be bullish on the stock, given that it’s trading above its historical levels and appears to already be pricing in strong results.
Fifty-nine percent of the 22 analysts tracked by FactSet have a Buy rating or the equivalent on P&G, with 36% rating it at Hold.
There is one bearish call on the stock.
The average analyst price target is $147.47.
Analysts are looking for P&G to earn $1.42 a share on revenue of $18.35 billion.
That compares with EPS of $1.16 last quarter and $1.37 in the year-ago period.
The company’s bottom line has surprised on the upside every quarter for the past five years.
P&G will host a conference call at 8:30 a.m. EDT on Tuesday.
